node.text:
With seven apartment buildings that are each unique in shape and form, the architecture of our project Nieuw Bergen is as unpredictable as it is exciting. Imaginary planes are drawn from the footprint of neighbouring residential buildings at an angle of 45 degrees, leading to buildings with jagged silhouettes. These ‘suncuts’ allow sunlight to pour into both homes and public spaces. The sloping roofs are ideally suited for solar panels and green roofs, while collective gardens and greenhouses crown a number of buildings - turning the neighbourhood into an urban oasis with plenty of green space for new residents to enjoy.
Of the seven buildings, two are renovations of existing buildings - one from the 1920s and another from the 1950s. All of this makes Nieuw Bergen a shining example of sustainable densification, connecting the traditional with the modern and continuing the informal character of the Bergen neighbourhood.

node.text:
"If you write a book you have only 26 letters and you can write all the books in the world with it. We do that with plants." - Piet Oudolf

In June, famed landscape designer Piet Oudolf visited the construction site of Valley for the first time to watch some of the first plants being added to the "rocky outcrops" on the façade of our building design. Oudolf's planting concept for the project enables a year-round green appearance, with flowering plants turning the publicly accessible terraced valley at the heart of the building into a sensory extravaganza of colours and scents 🌿🌸🐝🌺🪴

Video by wimzagtfilm

node.text:
MVRDV founding partner Winy Maas in conversation with environmental psychologist Joren van Dijk about De Oosterlingen. The project is a block of seven sustainable residential buildings, prominently located at the entrance to Amsterdam's Oostenburg Island, which is a formerly industrial area rapidly developing into a lively residential district. Designed for real estate developer Being, the buildings in the ‘barcode’ composition form a clear family, but each has its own character, with varying heights, roof shapes, and façades made of wood, glass, recycled brick, or biobased composite.

node.text:
Curious what the depot looks like inside? 👀 Join our co-founder Winy Maas for a fun tour of the building in this unique moment, right before the artworks are moved in. 

#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #architecture #design #interior #mirror #reflection #art #depot #boijmans #tour #peep #sneakpeek #film #movie #video #glass #view #rooftop #green #comingsoon #staytuned #rotterdam #netherlands

@boijmans @bambouwtechniek @gemeenterotterdam

Cover image @ossipvanduivenbode
Music composer: Benjamin Tissot / Bensound

node.text:
We're thinking back to the time MVRDVers Klaas Hofman, María López Calleja, and Andrei-Ducu Predescu starred in this very funny advert for @HP laptops 💻🎸🤘 In fact, we've spent much of the last year working away from the office as the advert suggests... but sadly NONE of that time was spent designing rock museums at rock festivals again.

Video by Alex Rigby and @180amsterdam
Ragnarock co-architects: @cobearchitects
Cover image @ossipvanduivenbode

#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #project #architecture #urbanism #design #rock #music #culture #cultural #transformation #funny #video #industrial #festival #public #experience #museum #gold #red #hp #renewal #roskilde #ragnarock #copenhagen #denmark @museumragnarock @roskildefestival @musiconroskilde⁠

node.text:
How does our design for @concordia_design Wrocław find its place in the long and complex history of Słodowa Island? In this video from @story_of_creation by The Making, our co-founder Nathalie de Vries explains how our design will cement Słodowa Island’s reputation as the place to be in Wrocław by engaging creatively with the island's history and working in harmony with its public space.
@concordia_design_wroclaw @demiurg_project @pkob_wegner

Co-architects: @q2studio
Cover image: @juliusz.k.sokolowski
Mural Artist: @alicjabiala

#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #architecture #new #project #building #design #history #transformation #open #public #space #slodowa #wroclaw #poland #video

node.text:
Our exhibition and new office in Berlin are the result of almost 30 years of hard work! In this video produced by PLANE—SITE, our Founding Partner Jacob van Rijs talks about the long journey between his first collaboration with Winy Maas and Nathalie de Vries, the 1991 project Berlin Voids, and the opening of the Berlin office in September. On the way, he gives us a brief glimpse of the archive currently on display at the MVRDV Haus Berlin exhibition, discusses the ideas that drive MVRDV's work, and explains the difference, in his view, between Dutch and German architects.

Video @plane_site
Cover image © Jan Bitter

node.text:
How do you become an architect? What are your ideas about when you design? How do you approach sustainability?
In this 4-episode series from the Almost Not Done Youth program, Dian, Noki, Lis, and Lewis get the rare opportunity to interview Winy Maas on his work, his thoughts about the city, and his latest project Depot Boijmans Van Beuningen.
Check out a preview of the video below and see the full episodes on Almost not done's Vimeo profile:
Episode 1.1 LIS: https://vimeo.com/441836491/1247a2ddb5
Episode 1.2 LEWIS: https://vimeo.com/441842203/b15b294ceb
Episode 1.3 NOKI: https://vimeo.com/441843667/eac1f78937
Episode 1.4 DIAN: https://vimeo.com/441844811/2fe78236ef

@boijmans @almostnotdone
Cover image by @ossipvanduivenbode

node.text:
#MVRDVnext The first episode of our series "Capacity 1.5: Explorations on Contactless Urbanism" is here! 📺 The built environment is based on the scale of the human body, and we all just became 1.5 meters wider. This new normal changes the impact of an individual body and this creates a ripple effect of change through all scales. In the first of eight episodes of "Capacity 1.5" we take a look at the scale of the individual - the you(s) - to understand how changes in our understanding of personal space could impact the future of our planet.
•
•
•
#mvrdv #architects #urbanists #designers #architecture #urbanism #urban #design #research #study #new #series #episode #human #scale #socialdistancing #mvrdvnext #video

node.text:
How can we create a vibrant neighbourhood that is in the tradition of the European city, but at the same time an update of it: historic, mixed and intimate, light, green, and dense? Our project Bastide Niel is a masterplan proposal to transform 35ha of former barracks and railyards in the centre of Bordeaux is an unprecedented opportunity to contribute to European urbanism.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The site, near the Garonne River, lies within walking distance of the UNESCO-listed historic centre of Bordeaux and was previously occupied by warehouses, rail embankments, and redundant barracks. Through careful retention and renovation of the existing buildings, along with controlled new development, a district will be created that integrates a wide variety of functions including housing along with a variety of public and cultural facilities.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Buildings in Bastide Niel must be designed with their impact upon the environment in mind. The masterplan stipulates that buildings in the neighbourhood should be light colours, reflecting sunlight and reducing the urban heat island effect; they should integrate solar panels and greenery into their roofs and loggias; and they should use wood construction whenever possible, minimising the carbon emissions of construction. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The 144 plots will host buildings from a diversity of architectural practices, mixing the work of local, national, and international designers. MVRDV coordinates with the architects of each project to ensure the cohesive realisation of all aspects of the masterplan.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to se more!⁠ 💙🌳⁠⁠
@engram_studio @mvrdvfrance⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
How can we create comfortable, green social spaces for our cities that can be enjoyed in all seasons? Le Signal was our proposal, designed alongside @fdmp_architectes, to build a new office of the Swiss national railways next to Geneva's Cornavin station.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Among the project's key features is a terraced social space, which begins in the lobby and wraps around the building. ⁠Filled with a diversity of plants, it creates an unconventional link between spaces and users, while its glass façade makes it open and visible to the city.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
From the outside, the project’s most notable feature is its sloped roof, preventing the building from blocking sunlight on the rue des Gares. The slope reaches its maximum height on the east of the building, where the site backs onto the train tracks. The combination of the slope and the building's irregular shape on this boundary results in the design’s unique, eye-catching roofline.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The design incorporates a variety of strategies to reduce energy consumption: the sloped roof incorporates solar panels, while the social space offers a crucial asset for climate control, working alongside heat exchange pumps to create an efficient passive ventilation system. In addition, the structure of the building was proposed to be built mainly in wood and the façade uses terracotta and aluminium, all of which can be sustainably sourced to reduce the embodied carbon of the construction.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to see more! ⁠🤗🚆⁠⁠
⁠Co-architect @fdmp_architectes⁠⁠
Renders @rzgraphics.studio⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Autumn is just around the corner! With that in mind, how can we design spaces that allow us to experience and enjoy seasonal change, even in dense cities? Our project Nieuw Bergen combines urban density with greenery, bringing nature closer to city dwellers 🌸🍃🍁⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Nieuw Bergen is a contemporary and progressive residential development, set to become a unique part of the city centre of Eindhoven. It combines the values of renovated and transformed buildings with new constructions.⁠⁠
⁠⁠⁠
Imaginary planes at an angle of 45 degrees are drawn from the footprint of neighbouring residential buildings, giving maximum sunlight for both houses and public space - and thus an appreciation of the changing light conditions throughout the year.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The 45-degree angles create unpredictable building forms with jagged silhouettes, resulting in a modern and optimistic atmosphere. Yet at the same time, they are reminiscent of traditional pitched roofs.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The oblique roof planes are ideally suited for installing solar panels and also accommodate green roofs. This concept is an evolution of the urban strategy tool we have been developing and actively applies in cities in need of sustainable densification.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Developed by @sdkvastgoed, Nieuw Bergen will get a hyper-modern feel and continues the informal character of the Bergen neighbourhood. Swipe to see more!⁠ 🌱⁠⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Renderings by @tobewaxed ⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
#BackToSchool How can we design flexible spaces that facilitate learning, interaction, and inspiration? Roskilde Festival Højskole is designed based on the ideals and values of the @roskildefestival, such as volunteer engagement, a humanistic focus and creative power!⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Designed with @cobearchitects, the school is an example of the Danish system of folk high schools, which deliver a “non-formal adult education” following the concept of “lifelong learning”. This system is based on the ideas of 19th-century Danish intellectual N.F.S. Grundtvig, who believed schools should educate their students to be active participants in society. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The design is based upon a “box-in-a-box” concept: colourful modules fill the warehouse-like shell of the main building, all arranged around a central spine cutting from one side of the building to the other. Alongside this route is a wooden tribune that acts as the communal heart of the school.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The boxes host a variety of different functions including an auditorium (named the Orange Stage in a nod to the main stage of the Festival) for 150 people, a music studio, a workshop, and classrooms for dance, art, and architecture.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
These functions are arranged into three zones: some host pursuits of the mind, including writing, thinking, debate, and leadership; others are focused on students’ use of their bodies, including dance and music functions, while the third zone hosts activities focused on the hand, including visual arts, architecture, and design.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠Swipe to see more! 🏫🎼🎵⁠⁠
@roskildefestivalhojskole ⁠⁠@roskildefestival @musiconroskilde⁠⁠⁠⁠
⁠⁠⁠
Co-architects: @cobearchitects⁠⁠⁠⁠
📸@ossipvanduivenbode⁠⁠⁠
⁠⁠⁠

node.text:
#BackToSchool We need welcoming spaces for study, learning, and finding inspiration! Taking the form of a mountain of books on the town's market square, our design of a library in Spijkenisse is an advertisement for reading! ⁠📚💡⁠
⁠
Book Mountain is a monument to the power and pleasure of reading. Stacking the building's various functions produces its pyramidal form, which is wrapped in 480 meters of bookshelves and reading spaces.⁠
⁠
These bookshelves are made from recycled flowerpots a nod to Spijkenisse’s agricultural past. The shelves are sustainable, affordable and even fireproof.⁠
⁠
In addition to the library, the building houses an environmental education centre, a chess club, an auditorium, meeting rooms, commercial offices and retail space. ⁠Swipe to see more! 🔖⁠
⁠
@boekenbergspijkenisse⁠
📸@dariascagliola⁠ ⁠
⁠

node.text:
#BackToSchool We love the fascinating repositories of knowledge that libraries offer! We think they're even more exciting when they also facilitate social interaction. Here's our award-winning Tianjin Binhai Library, a project updating the library typology to this century's needs.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The 33,700m2 cultural centre features a luminous spherical auditorium and floor-to-ceiling cascading bookcases. It functions not only as an education centre but as a social space and connector from the park into the cultural district.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Terraced bookshelves which echo the form of the sphere create a topographic interior landscape whose contours reach out and wrap around the façade. In this way, the stepped bookshelves within are represented on the outside with each level doubling up as a louvre.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Tianjin Binhai Library also tells the story of what happens when not everything goes to plan... The tight construction schedule forced one essential part of the concept to be dropped: access to the upper bookshelves from rooms placed behind the atrium. This change was made locally and against our advice, rendering access to the upper shelves impossible. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
But we keep up hope, as the full vision for the Tianjin Library may yet be realised! Until then the upper shelves of the library remain empty – with perforated aluminium plates printed to represent books – a remnant of the original design. Swipe to see more! 📚⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸 @ossipvanduivenbode⁠⁠

node.text:
How can we create spaces that respect the human scale, while merging the past with the future? Our design for Fabryczna Offices draws inspiration from the distinct industrial textile heritage of Poland's third-largest city, reimagining it for contemporary use.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The 13-storey building integrates into its surroundings with a glazed brick and glass façade surrounding a new plaza.⁠ The façade, with a colour scheme that blends from red to metallic grey, refers both to the past and the city’s future ambition.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The plinth, a band of retail spaces on the ground floor with offices above, is designed with a depth that allows for maximum daylight on all floors. The plinth and tower are rounded and curved to create a series of smaller volumes that afford the project a more intimate scale and provide individual identity to future tenants.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The courtyard has an opening towards the culture centre and a passage towards Kilinskiego Street with the intention to introduce a new walking route through the area, so that the 55-metre tower at the heart of the design welcomes passers-by, while an underground tunnel connects Fabryczna Offices to the central station and other parts of the city.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The private green roof and public courtyard by Lola landscape architects are designed as a family of semi-public spaces characterized by a large variety of vegetation and sunlit terraces.⁠ 🌿⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to see more 😌⁠⁠
Landscape design @lolalandscapearchitects⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
How can we bring a more intimate form of urban life to an area dominated by roadways? Our project Hongqiao Flower Building is part of our masterplan Hongqiao CBD, a sustainable office and retail district which differentiates itself from other CBDs in Shanghai with its public space and pedestrian environment.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The masterplan comprises ten cubic office towers, an underground shopping centre, cultural programme, parking and a plaza. It creates an inner courtyard space surrounded by office buildings, a sunken plaza with shops connected to the metro station and a pedestrian path for circulation. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The Hongqiao Flower Building itself merges the footprint of four towers to create a shaded and intimate plaza below. The ground floor features retail space, while connections between the uppermost floors allow for flexible tenancy.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
With its rounded shape and cantilevering floors that reduce sunlight exposure, the building achieves a 3-star Green Building Label, the best energy performance rating in China.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
With its good public transport links and pedestrian connectivity, the Hongqiao district attracts people to enjoy a calm and intimate atmosphere, in contrast to the bustling surrounds of Shanghai's outskirts.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to see more! ⁠🏢🌿⁠⁠
📸 Shen Photo⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Tickets 🎟 for the Depot Boijmans Van Beuningen, the world’s first publicly accessible art depot, are now available! ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The grand opening of the building will take place on November 6th 2021 – offering visitors a chance, for the first time ever, to see all 151,000 artworks in the museum's collection under one roof.⁠😊⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠Over the past three months, the Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen has moved its entire collection of paintings, drawings, sculptures, design objects, and other artistic items from across five centuries into its new home – a rehousing on an unprecedented scale for the Museum. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In the depot, artefacts are stored according to their climatic requirements, as opposed to movement or era. Each storage space is climate controlled, with five different climate zones arranged according to works of art produced with different materials: metal, plastic, organic/inorganic, and photography. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
When the building opens, not only will its storage spaces be filled with art, but also the atrium will display selected works in the 13 glass display cases peppered between the criss-crossing stairs.⁠⁠⁠
⁠⁠
On the building’s roof, visitors will find a restaurant and rooftop forest, with 75 multi-stemmed birch trees joined by smaller conifers and grasses.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Link in bio to book your visit! ⁠🖥⁠⁠
⁠⁠
📸@ossipvanduivenbode⁠⁠
@boijmans ⁠@bambouwtechniek @rotterdam_info⁠⁠⁠

node.text:
How can we design buildings that create more fluid connections between lower and upper levels and open up to the neighbourhood? Our project Bałtyk is a mixed-use building featuring office spaces, restaurants, and scenic terraces offering panoramic views all across the city. 🌆⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Bałtyk changes its shape depending on the viewing angle and it is bold and significant with its depth in the volume. Towards the south, a slope of cascading patios offers outdoor spaces to the users of the building. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The façade is floor-to-ceiling glass with vertical louvres of glass fibre concrete softening the impact of the sun without losing the vistas over the city and zoo.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Diagonal shapes are turned into terraces for users, and this thins out as it ascends allowing for less square meters of offices in return for more public space below. The flexible office space is limited to a depth of seven metres allowing daylight to generously penetrate the workspaces.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
A building that is very different from all four sides and responds to the historicity of the site located on what used to be the old Baltyk cinema, from which the project takes its name.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to see more!⁠🏢🏨👩‍💼👨‍💼⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Co-architects: Natkaniec Olechnicki Architekci ⁠⁠

node.text:
How exciting is it to totally switch what would have been wasted into something new! Can you imagine that our project Roskilde Festival Højskole (Folk High School in Roskilde) used to be a former concrete factory?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Roskilde Festival Højskole is the first newly-established and built folk high school of its kind in Denmark in 45 years and is closely linked to the world-famous Roskilde Music Festival, which every year temporarily turns this small town on the outskirts of Copenhagen into the fourth-largest city in Denmark.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The school itself is housed in a former concrete factory, reusing the original structure’s columns and roof but replacing the walls and interior, giving special vibes of music, art, activism – but most of all, freedom.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The design is based upon a “box-in-a-box” concept: colourful modules fill the warehouse-like shell of the main building, all arranged around a central spine cutting from one side of the building to the other. Alongside this route is a wooden tribune that acts as the communal heart of the school.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠Swipe to see more!⁠ 🎵🎹⁠⁠
⁠⁠

node.text:
Natural light is a powerful architectural tool. Our project Chongwenmen M·CUBE is wrapped in a pearlescent ceramic façade that at different times appears either grey or colourful, creating a subtle façade that does not need large LED screens to stand out and catch the attention of the passers-by.⁠ 🌞🌇⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Hand-glazed in China, these tiles were made by applying three layers of glaze to the ceramic, and firing at a different temperature each time.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Our co-founder Jacob van Rijs remarks, “We designed the Chongwenmen M·CUBE so that the building continuously displays new patterns and colours. Depending on the weather and light conditions and where you stand, the façade might look subtly grey, or it might shine with all the colours of the rainbow."⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The surface treatment of the façade also breaks up the mass of the building while responding to the light and view requirements of the interior program. While some areas of the surface were required to have blind facades to accommodate the stores behind, other stores are able to use diffuse light to their advantage, and here the ceramic tiles are used in a checkerboard pattern. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe to see more! 🌅👉⁠⁠
⁠⁠
